--- title: "2.7 — John Stuart Mill and the Decline of Classical Economics — Class Content" execute: freeze: auto --- ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal"} # Meeting Dates *Thursday, October 13, 2022* ::: ## Overview Today we cover John Stuart Mill and the "apex" and decline of the Classical School of Economics. ## Readings ### Required Readings: - John Stuart Mill & *Principles of Political Economy* in *Reader* - Ch.6 "John Stuart Mill and the Decline of Classical Economics" in Landreth & Colander - Ch.5 in Blaug ### Recommended Readings: The following Wikipedia entries can also provide more background: - [ John Stuart Mill](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Stuart_Mill) Since I also briefly digress into Henry George, Georgism, and the Single Value tax: - [ Wikpedia: Henry George](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_George) - [ Wikpedia: Georgism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georgism) ### Questions to Help Your Reading - What is the proper method of economics, according to Mill? - What are Mill’s politics? - What is the difference between production and distribution in Mill’s theory? - What does Mill think of Say’s Law? - How does Mill address the criticisms of economics from socialists and other critics of Ricardo? - How much is Mill a classical economist, and how does he differ from Ricardo? ## Slides Below, you can find the slides in two formats. Clicking the image will bring you to the html version of the slides in a new tab. The lower button will allow you to download a PDF version of the slides. ::: callout-tip You can type h to see a special list of viewing options, and type o for an outline view of all the slides. ::: I suggest printing the slides beforehand and using them to take additional notes in class (*not everything* is in the slides)!
